attr.fort.name: Chittorgarh Fort
attr.fort.desc: A UNESCO World Heritage Site and the largest fort in India. A symbol of resilience and architectural brilliance.
attr.padmini.name: Padmini Palace
attr.padmini.desc: A legendary palace surrounded by water, famous for the bravery of Rani Padmini. A masterpiece of architectural grace.
attr.bassi.name: Bassi Wildlife Sanctuary
attr.bassi.desc: A haven for nature lovers, home to panthers, wild boars, and migratory birds.
attr.temple.name: Sanwariaji Temple
attr.temple.desc: Dedicated to Lord Krishna, this temple is a significant pilgrimage site known for its grandeur.
attr.vijay.name: Vijay Stambh (Victory Tower)
attr.vijay.desc: Built by Rana Kumbha to commemorate his victory over Mahmud Khilji. A 9-story marvel.
attr.kirti.name: Kirti Stambha (Tower of Fame)
attr.kirti.desc: A 12th-century tower dedicated to Adinath, the first Jain Tirthankara. A masterpiece of Solanki architectural style.
attr.kalika.name: Kalika Mata Temple
attr.kalika.desc: Originally a Sun Temple built in the 8th century, dedicated to Goddess Bhadrakali.
attr.jain.name: Sattavis Jain Temples
attr.jain.desc: A group of 27 ancient Jain temples showcasing intricate carvings and spiritual serenity.
attr.gaumukh.name: Gaumukh Reservoir
attr.gaumukh.desc: A sacred water tank shaped like a cow's mouth, located near the Vijay Stambh.
attr.fateh.name: Fateh Prakash Palace
attr.fateh.desc: A magnificent palace built by Rana Fateh Singh, now a museum showcasing royal artifacts and history.
attr.menal.name: Menal Waterfall & Temple
attr.menal.desc: A stunning waterfall complex with 11th-century temples, often called the 'Mini Khajuraho' of Rajasthan.
attr.meera.name: Meera Bai Temple
attr.meera.desc: Dedicated to the mystic poet-saint Meera Bai, this temple is a symbol of devotion and love for Lord Krishna.
attr.ratan.name: Ratan Singh Palace
attr.ratan.desc: Overlooking the Ratneshwar Talab, this palace offers a glimpse into the royal lifestyle of the Mewar rulers.
attr.kumbha_palace.name: Rana Kumbha Palace
attr.kumbha_palace.desc: The oldest and largest palace in the fort, associated with the legend of Rani Padmini's Jauhar.
attr.kumbha_shyam.name: Kumbha Shyam Temple
attr.kumbha_shyam.desc: Built by Rana Kumbha, this temple is dedicated to Lord Vishnu and features unique Indo-Aryan architecture.
attr.light.name: Light & Sound Show
attr.light.desc: A mesmerizing evening show narrating the history of Chittorgarh Fort.
chron.hero.title: The Mewar Chronicles
chron.hero.sub: Legends of Sacrifice, Valour, and Devotion
legend.padmini.title: Rani Padmini
legend.padmini.subtitle: The Saga of Grace and Sacrifice
legend.padmini.desc: Known for her ethereal beauty and sharp intellect, Rani Padmini is a symbol of supreme sacrifice. To protect the honour of Chittorgarh from the siege of Alauddin Khalji, she led the heroic 'Jauhar' along with thousands of brave women, a tale that still echoes in the fort's wind.
legend.pratap.title: Maharana Pratap
legend.pratap.subtitle: The Unyielding Spirit
legend.pratap.desc: The lion of Mewar who never bowed to the Mughal Empire. Along with his legendary horse Chetak, he fought for the freedom of his land in the battle of Haldighati. His life was a testament to the belief that liberty is worth more than a golden throne.
legend.panna.title: Panna Dhai
legend.panna.subtitle: The Ultimate Sacrifice
legend.panna.desc: A nursemaid like no other, who sacrificed her own son, Chandan, to save the infant Prince Udai Singh from an assassin. Her unwavering loyalty ensured the continuation of the Mewar dynasty, proving that some bonds are deeper than blood.
legend.meera.title: Meera Bai
legend.meera.subtitle: The Devotion of the Soul
legend.meera.desc: A princess who renounced royal luxuries for the love of Lord Krishna. Her soulful bhajans and fearless devotion redefined spirituality, reminding the world that the greatest strength lies in pure, unshakeable love.
chron.footer.aiNote: The cinematic illustrations in this chronicle were reimagined using advanced Artificial Intelligence to visualize the timeless legends of Mewar.
chron.footer.heritage: Chittorgarh: Where history is etched in stone and soul.

fact.title: Did You Know?
fact.1: Chittorgarh Fort is the largest fort complex in India and Asia, sprawling over 700 acres.
fact.2: The fort originally had 84 water bodies, including ponds, wells, and stepwells.
fact.3: Vijay Stambh (Tower of Victory) features 157 narrow steps to reach the 9th floor.
fact.4: The fort was recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2013 for its architectural grandeur.
fact.5: Meera Bai, the legendary poet-saint and devotee of Lord Krishna, resided within these fort walls.
fact.6: The fort's history dates back to the 7th century, originally built by the Maurya Dynasty.
fact.7: There are 7 massive gateways (Pols) to enter the citadel, each with its own historical significance.
fact.8: Rani Padmini's Palace is uniquely built amidst a beautiful lotus pool.
fact.9: Kirti Stambh (Tower of Fame) is a 12th-century tower dedicated to the first Jain Tirthankara, Adinath.
fact.10: The Gaumukh Reservoir is a sacred water body fed by a spring that flows from a carved cow's mouth.

plan.1.title: 1 Day: The Royal Heritage Tour (Premium)
plan.1.desc: A meticulously curated journey through 1300 years of valor. Experience the grandeur of the largest fort in India with deep historical immersion.
plan.1.sch.0.title: Arrival & The Seven Gates
plan.1.sch.0.activity: Begin your ascent driving through the seven historic pols (gates): Padan, Bhairon, Hanuman, Ganesh, Jodla, Laxman, and finally the main Ram Pol. Tip: Stop at the memorial chhatris of Jaimal and Patta between Bhairon and Hanuman Pol to pay respects to the martyrs of the 1568 siege.
plan.1.sch.1.title: Rana Kumbha Palace & Museums
plan.1.sch.1.activity: Explore the ruins of the oldest palace in the fort. Visit the Government Museum inside Fateh Prakash Palace to see ancient sculptures, medieval weaponry, and royal artifacts. Legend says Rani Padmini performed Jauhar in the cellars of Rana Kumbha Palace.
plan.1.sch.2.title: Towers of Victory & Fame
plan.1.sch.2.activity: Marvel at the Vijay Stambha (Tower of Victory), a 9-story marvel carved with thousands of Hindu deities. Pro Tip: The best view of the fort is from the top floor. Nearby, visit the Kirti Stambha (Tower of Fame), a 12th-century Jain monument dedicated to Adinath.
plan.1.sch.3.title: Temples of Devotion
plan.1.sch.3.activity: Visit the Kumbha Shyam Temple (Varaha avatar of Vishnu) and the Meera Bai Temple. Sit for a moment where the poet-saint Meera Bai once sang bhajans for Lord Krishna. The intricate carvings here are a photographer's delight.
plan.1.sch.4.title: Royal Rajasthani Feast
plan.1.sch.4.activity: Head to 'Chokhi Dhani' or 'Hotel Pratap Palace' nearby for an authentic thali featuring Dal Baati Churma, Gatte ki Sabzi, and Bajre ki Roti. Experience the hospitality of Mewar.
plan.1.sch.5.title: Rani Padmini's Palace
plan.1.sch.5.activity: Visit the summer pavilion of Queen Padmini, surrounded by a lotus pool. This is the legendary spot where Alauddin Khilji is said to have glimpsed her reflection. The gardens here are lush and perfect for a leisurely walk.
plan.1.sch.6.title: Gaumukh Reservoir & Kalika Mata
plan.1.sch.6.activity: Walk down to the Gaumukh Reservoir, fed by a perennial spring from a carved cow's mouth. It's a serene spot teeming with fish. Then, visit the 8th-century Kalika Mata Temple (originally a Sun temple) to witness the sunset prayer.
plan.1.sch.7.title: Lumiere: Sound & Light Show
plan.1.sch.7.activity: Conclude with the spectacular Sound & Light show (English/Hindi) at the fort complex. Watch the history of Chittorgarh come alive through lights projected on the ancient walls. (Ticket: Approx ₹100, varying by season).
plan.2.title: 2 Days: Wildlife & Waterfalls Expedition
plan.2.desc: Beyond the fort lies the untamed beauty of the Aravallis. Discover leopards in the wild and ancient temples hidden by waterfalls.
plan.2.sch.0.title: Complete Heritage Tour
plan.2.sch.0.activity: Follow the comprehensive 1-Day Itinerary detailed above for a full immersion into the fort's history.
plan.2.sch.1.title: Sunrise Drive to Bassi
plan.2.sch.1.activity: Depart early for Bassi Wildlife Sanctuary (25km). The morning mist over the Aravalli hills offers stunning photographic opportunities.
plan.2.sch.2.title: Jungle Safari
plan.2.sch.2.activity: Board a Gypsy for a safari. Keep your eyes peeled for Panthers, Sloth Bears, Hyenas, and the Four-horned Antelope. The sanctuary is also a birdwatcher's paradise (Peacocks, Eagles, Hawkes).
plan.2.sch.3.title: Bassi & Orai Dams
plan.2.sch.3.activity: Visit the Bassi Dam and Orai Dam. The stillness of the water against the rugged hills is mesmerizing. Perfect for a mid-morning break and nature photography.
plan.2.sch.4.title: Picnic at Menal
plan.2.sch.4.activity: Drive to Menal (approx 60km). Enjoy a picnic lunch near the gorge. The area is lush green, especially post-monsoon.
plan.2.sch.5.title: Menal: The Mini Khajuraho
plan.2.sch.5.activity: Explore the Mahanaleshwar Temple complex (11th Century). The erotic sculptures and intricate stone carvings rival those of Khajuraho. Witness the Menal River plunging 150 feet into a gorge—a breathtaking sight.
plan.2.sch.6.title: Rural Drive Back
plan.2.sch.6.activity: Return to Chittorgarh via the scenic rural route. Witness local village life, cattle herders, and traditional mud houses.
plan.2.sch.7.title: Dinner at Castle Bijaipur
plan.2.sch.7.activity: Optional: drive to Castle Bijaipur (heritage hotel) for a royal dinner experience, or enjoy local street food (Mirchi Vada, Pyaaz Kachori) in Chittorgarh market.
plan.3.title: 3 Days: The Soul of Mewar
plan.3.desc: A holistic journey covering History, Nature, Divinity, and Art. Meet the artisans of Akola and seek blessings at Sanwariya Seth.
plan.3.sch.0.title: History & Nature
plan.3.sch.0.activity: Complete the 2-Day Itinerary covering the Fort, Bassi Sanctuary, and Menal Waterfalls.
plan.3.sch.1.title: Pilgrimage to Mandraphiya
plan.3.sch.1.activity: Drive 40km to the Sanwariya Seth Temple. Dedicated to Lord Krishna, this temple is famous for its opulence and the belief that the Lord is a business partner to his devotees.
plan.3.sch.2.title: Akola: The Indigo Village
plan.3.sch.2.activity: Visit Akola (Chhipon-ka-Akola). Watch the master craftsmen perform 'Dabu' printing—a unique mud-resist technique. See the indigo dyeing pits that have been used for generations.
plan.3.sch.3.title: Traditional Village Lunch
plan.3.sch.3.activity: Experience hospitality in a rural home or a local eatery. Try 'Makki ki Raab' (Corn soup) and fresh buttermilk.
plan.3.sch.4.title: Artisan Shopping
plan.3.sch.4.activity: Purchase fabrics directly from the source. Akola prints are famous for not bleeding color. Pick up bedsheets, sarees, and dress materials at unbeatable prices.
plan.3.sch.5.title: Local Market Exploration
plan.3.sch.5.activity: Return to Chittorgarh city. Explore Sadar Bazaar and Station Road. Look for 'Thewa' jewelry (gold on glass), wooden toys from Bassi, and colorful Jutits (shoes).
plan.3.sch.6.title: Royal Farewell
plan.3.sch.6.activity: Conclude your trip with a rooftop dinner overlooking the illuminated Fort. Reflect on 1300 years of history, the roar of the wild, and the color of indigo.
